text: I want to thank Chairwoman McCarthy, Ranking Member Platts and members of the
label: TITLE

text: Sub-committee on Healthy Families and Communities for holding this hearing to explore
label: BODY

text: the gang prevention activities on Long Island to learn what might be replicated across the
label: BODY

text: country.   The reduction of gang recruitment efforts along with prevention of gang related
label: BODY

text: crime is essential to the safety of all residents of our country.  The FBI Long Island
label: BODY

text: Office reports that the Mara Salvatrucha, or MS-13, gang has been deemed to be a "High
label: BODY

text: Threat" to the northeast section of our country due to its involvement in murder, assaults
label: BODY

text: with weapons, firearms possession, drug distribution, extortion from businesses,
label: BODY

text: prostitution and robbery.
label: BODY

text: The immediate focus of the Freeport Police Departments efforts to mitigate gang
label: BODY

text: recruitment was a Gang Awareness Suppression and Prevention Program (GASPP).  The
label: BODY

text: demographics of the street gang population encompass a broad spectrum of race,
label: BODY

text: ethnicity, gender and age and the program provides gang related information to parents,
label: BODY

text: community members, school staffs, and the work force in an effort to reduce gang
label: BODY

text: recruitment
label: BODY

text: The awareness component of GASPP provides a description of various behaviors, and
label: BODY

text: physical observations, which together or in some cases independently, are indicative of
label: BODY

text: gang involvement.  While the information provided in the GASPP brochure (attachment
label: BODY

text: # 1) is representative of gang indicators, it is not all-inclusive.  Symbols, colors, hand
label: BODY

text: signs, clothing and gang codes consistently change due to Police awareness and fashion
label: BODY

text: trends.  The changes in team logos and colors of professional sports organizations are
label: BODY

text: frequently the impetus for such changes.
label: BODY

text: The prevention element of GASPP encompasses many youth-oriented activities.  These
label: BODY

text: include mentoring programs for elementary school students, along with a guide for
label: BODY

text: parents that advises them of the many programs available to their child as an alternative
label: BODY

text: to gangs.  Community members and businesses are requested to engage in positive
label: BODY

text: interaction with adolescents to encourage appropriate social interaction.  Business
label: BODY

text: owners, residents, and team coaches, are all requested to actively communicate with
label: BODY

text: students who are engaging in inappropriate behavior.  This is done in a manner that is
label: BODY

text: courteous and provides positive instruction as a means of conveying the necessity of civil
label: BODY

text: behavior and to further individual achievement.   The School District Superintendent,
label: BODY

text: together with high and middle school administrators, meet monthly with a Freeport
label: BODY

text: Police Department command staff member to develop strategy to prevent gang activity in
label: BODY

text: the schools and community based upon recent gang incidents.  Informal sharing occurs
label: BODY

text: between the school staff and police in close time proximity to any gang involved offense
label: BODY

text: when students are participants.  (Please see attachment #1 for detailed explanation of the
label: BODY

text: GASPP program.)
label: BODY

text: The suppression element of GASPP involves various law enforcement programs that are
label: BODY

text: performed independently or in conjunction with community resources to discourage
label: BODY

text: gang-related activity.  Suppression efforts include partnerships with federal and state
label: BODY

text: prosecutors, along with a task force made up of federal, state and local law enforcement
label: BODY

text: members.  Participation in the FBI Gang Task Force has provided additional law
label: BODY

text: enforcement resources for conducting criminal investigations of gangs with a focus on
label: BODY

text: their leadership.  These investigations have resulted in the arrest and successful
label: BODY

text: prosecution of sixty-five members of Mara Salvatrucha, or MS-13. Other gangs that are
label: BODY

text: prevalent through out Long Island such as the Latin King, Bloods, and Crips are being
label: BODY

text: investigated for crimes similar to the type committed by MS-13, by both the FBI Gang
label: BODY

text: Task Force and local law enforcement.   The Federal Court, without a prior conviction of
label: BODY

text: a predicate felony, may not prosecute individual gang members, who are seventeen years
label: BODY

text: of age or less.  Therefore gang members who have a defense based on their age are
label: BODY

text: prosecuted locally.  The MS 13 members who were arrested were involved in the
label: BODY

text: commission of various violent crimes that include dealing drugs, possession of firearms,
label: BODY

text: rape, robbery and murder.
label: BODY

text: Another cooperative gang suppression effort is a partnership with the Nassau County
label: BODY

text: Probation Department that teams Police Officers with Probation Officers.  The Probation
label: BODY

text: Department Officers lead the teams that visit the residences of probationers who are gang
label: BODY

text: members.  These visits serve to ensure that the probationers are not in violation of any
label: BODY

text: terms of their probation.  This compliance program also  verifies that gang members are
label: BODY

text: not associating with other gang members or in possession of any firearms or drugs.  It
label: BODY

text: also provides a means to establish that they are abiding by curfew restrictions, thereby
label: BODY

text: discouraging their participation in crime.
label: BODY

text: Supplementing traditional gang prevention techniques, the Freeport Police Department
label: BODY

text: has developed and implemented a Home Visit Program (HVP).  The HVP has been
label: BODY

text: designed to assist the parents of gang members by helping them recognize their child's
label: BODY

text: association with a gang.  This usually takes place prior to an arrest of their son or
label: BODY

text: daughter.  After a Police Officer has confirmed that an individual is involved with a gang
label: BODY

text: and the information is passed on to the Commanding Officer of the Freeport Police
label: BODY

text: Department’s Community Response Unit (CRU).  Two Detectives are assigned to
label: BODY

text: conduct a home visit of the gang member's family to discuss their child's participation in
label: BODY

text: the gang and advise them of the resources available to the family to help them discourage
label: BODY

text: their child's further participation in the gang.   The initial reaction to the police visit is
label: BODY

text: denial of their child’s involvement.  Only after the detectives present the parents with
label: BODY

text: evidence that includes gang indicators such as tattoos, limited clothing attire restricted by
label: BODY

text: color, letters or product initials, observation of hand signing, and their child or friends,
label: BODY

text: are not hearing challenged, along with drawings, and gang paraphernalia in their school
label: BODY

text: bags or books do, the parents realize that their child is involved with gangs.  In some
label: BODY

text: instances, parents have relocated their son or daughter with relatives in other states or
label: BODY

text: even other countries.  Other parents have expressed frustration and a lack of hope with
label: BODY

text: regard to their child’s future.  A small percentage are currently gang members themselves
label: BODY

text: or don’t see a problem with their child’s involved gang membership.   During testimony
label: BODY

text: to the Nassau County Legislation Public Safety Committee, a Roosevelt, N.Y.
label: BODY

text: Community Activist testified that the gang members in her neighborhood helped her
label: BODY

text: grow up and she saw no problem with them hanging out with her children.  She further
label: BODY

text: stated that the only gang she was afraid of was the gang dressed in blue that drive white
label: BODY

text: cars with blue and orange stripes.  This was a reference to the Nassau County Police
label: BODY

text: Department.  To make the HVP more effective, a partnership has been established with
label: BODY

text: the Freeport Pride Youth Outreach organization, that has resulted in providing the parents
label: BODY

text: with follow up referral services and involvement by their social workers.
label: BODY

text: School Based Programs
label: BODY

text: The Freeport Police Department Adopt-A-Cop Program is another activity that was
label: BODY

text: developed to discourage youth from entering a gang.  The Adopt A Cop Program was
label: BODY

text: formulated to provide a positive informal interaction between students and police
label: BODY

text: officers.  The program requires the "adoption" of one police officer by each 4th grade
label: BODY

text: class who will meet with their "adopted" Officer at the onset of the program and monthly
label: BODY

text: thereafter throughout the school year. The officers who are involved in the Adopt A Cop
label: BODY

text: program are volunteers.  Of the ninety-two Freeport police officers, twenty-eight
label: BODY

text: volunteer as Adopt A Cops.
label: BODY

text: During the monthly meeting, officers conduct an open exchange of ideas and discussions
label: BODY

text: with their students that centers around the fore mentioned goals and objectives.  The
label: BODY

text: officers also schedule tours of Police Headquarters and attend the school trips by their
label: BODY

text: respective classes.  At the completion of each meeting, each student composes a letter to
label: BODY

text: their police officer including any comments or questions which pertains to the prior
label: BODY

text: meeting, or other police related concerns.  The officer responds with a general letter to
label: BODY

text: the entire class, which is read to them by their teacher in between meetings.
label: BODY

text: At the end of the school year, all of the fourth grade students, their adopted Police
label: BODY

text: Officers and additional Police resources, celebrate the end of their school year together
label: BODY

text: with Adopt A Cop Day.  The day is filled with interactive presentations that include tours
label: BODY

text: of a Police helicopter, Horse Mounted Officer, SCUBA and K-9 demonstrations.  Pizza,
label: BODY

text: hot dogs, soda and ice cream are enjoyed by all of the day's participants.  In addition each
label: BODY

text: child is also given an Adopt a Cop tee shirt.
label: BODY

text: Goals and Objectives:
label: BODY

text: The goals and objectives of the Adopt A Cop program are to:
label: BODY

text: A) Encourage the mutually beneficial exchange of information and concerns between the
label: BODY

text: Adopted Cop and his/her class.
label: BODY

text: B) Provide a positive police officer role model, thereby dispelling negative police
label: BODY

text: stereotypes.
label: BODY

text: C) Educate children about their safety, and discuss methods which the children may use
label: BODY

text: to avoid potential hazardous situations, including gang recruitment efforts.
label: BODY

text: D)       Discuss projects and non-violent forms of entertainment as a positive alternative
label: BODY

text: to questionable media entertainment.
label: BODY

text: E)        Provide an avenue for children to discuss positive alternate means to resolve
label: BODY

text: conflict, or express anger or frustration as an alternative to violence or
label: BODY

text: alcohol/drug use.
label: BODY

text: F)        Provide insight into the function of police officers, and encourage students to
label: BODY

text: consider law enforcement as a possible career.
label: BODY

text: G) Contribute to the development of the children who participate in the Adopt A
label: BODY

text: Cop program.
label: BODY

text: Each of the officers who participate as Adopt-A-Cop Program volunteers receive the
label: BODY

text: Freeport Police Department Community Service Award at the bi-annual award dinner.
label: BODY

text: This program is currently in its eleventh year of operation.
label: BODY

text: The Safe Schools Healthy Students grant had funded a similar but much smaller police
label: BODY

text: mentoring program that was designed for middle school students, who were recognized
label: BODY

text: to be considered "at risk" of gang involvement.  This program had been proposed by the
label: BODY

text: Freeport Police Department to the Safe Schools Healthy Students Program Committee
label: BODY

text: Members.  The committee included the Freeport School District, Nassau County BOCES,
label: BODY

text: Operation Pride, Freeport Youth Outreach, and the South Shore Child Guidance Center.
label: BODY

text: Middle school students were selected as the program participants due to a conscious
label: BODY

text: belief by the program membership that this mentoring program would complement the
label: BODY

text: Adopt-A-Cop program. Due to grant funding limitations, the program was limited with
label: BODY

text: regard to the number of participants to achieve the greatest impact with limited resources.
label: BODY

text: It was decided that middle school administrators and teachers would select those students
label: BODY

text: they believed to be “at risk” of gang involvement for this program.
label: BODY

text: Ultimately the program would include this group of middle school students who the
label: BODY

text: committee members believed would benefit the most from interaction with police
label: BODY

text: officers.  The programs six police officers would interact weekly during a shared school
label: BODY

text: based lunch meeting.  On weekends, students and police officers would jointly participate
label: BODY

text: in sports, trips, and movie outings.  The officers received an hourly rate, which was
label: BODY

text: substantially less than their police officer salaries as per diem school district employees.
label: BODY

text: Unfortunately, in spite of its success, when the grant funding expired, the school district
label: BODY

text: was unable to continue the program.
label: BODY

text: Gang prevention efforts must also include educational programs that assist adolescents in
label: BODY

text: achieving important developmental skills.  In 2004, the Freeport Police Department
label: BODY

text: introduced an employment skills workshop designed to facilitate employment
label: BODY

text: opportunities for middle school students.  The workshop provides these students with
label: BODY

text: insight into the job application process, interview, preparation and employment
label: BODY

text: expectations.  The information provided affords students the opportunity to be readily
label: BODY

text: prepared to seek employment opportunities, thereby offering a counter balance to the
label: BODY

text: limitations imposed by gang membership.  Gangs grant status to members who are
label: BODY

text: violent, possess an active and lengthy criminal record and embrace a disregard of
label: BODY

text: societies value on life, individual responsibility and achievement.   These traits are
label: BODY

text: counterproductive to being successful in seeking employment.  The aforementioned gang
label: BODY

text: tenets preclude a chance for a successful job interview in contrast to the Employment
label: BODY

text: Skills Workshop.   (Please see attachment #2, Employment Skills Workshop).
label: BODY

text: Community Partnership
label: BODY

text: The aforementioned police initiatives were presented as initial efforts to address the
label: BODY

text: proliferation of gangs and related crime issues.  Continuing in this vein in 2002, Mayor
label: BODY

text: Glacken and the Board of Trustees with the Freeport Police Department, in conjunction
label: BODY

text: with the Freeport school district, formed a consortium of various organizations and
label: BODY

text: institutions that are associated with the Freeport community.  The organization was
label: BODY

text: formed and named the Officials Working Group (OWG) for the purpose of preventing
label: BODY

text: gang related crime through the concerted utilization of new and existing resources.  The
label: BODY

text: main committee meets monthly, while the sub-committees meet during the month and
label: BODY

text: report on their progress at the main monthly meeting.
label: BODY

text: Representation on the committee rapidly expanded to include the Nassau County District
label: BODY

text: Attorney's Office, Nassau County Youth Board, Freeport Parent Teachers Association
label: BODY

text: (PTA), Hofstra University Liberty Partnership, Nassau County Coalition Against
label: BODY

text: Domestic Violence, Junior Achievement, Nassau County Equal Opportunity
label: BODY

text: Commission, Freeport Recreation Department, Freeport Pride, Education Tutorial
label: BODY

text: Services, Struggling To Reunite Our New Generation (STRONG), along with
label: BODY

text: representatives of various religious clergy and community advocates.  The School
label: BODY

text: Superintendent chairs the committee.
label: BODY

text: In the beginning, the committee decided to focus on reducing crime by addressing street
label: BODY

text: gang violence and related anti-social behavior in the schools and community.  Committee
label: BODY

text: members determined that the first objective would be to discourage gang recruitment
label: BODY

text: efforts through community and parental awareness presentations.  A revised gang
label: BODY

text: awareness program was developed from the pre-existing Freeport Police Department
label: BODY

text: Gang Awareness, Suppression & Prevention (GASP) program.  The expanded Gang
label: BODY

text: Awareness Program (GAP) is designed to inform community members, with an emphasis
label: BODY

text: on parents of students, about how to determine if a person is involved in a gang through
label: BODY

text: the identification of specific characteristics unique to street gang members.  In addition,
label: BODY

text: the presentation list the reasons people join gangs, along with a description of their rites
label: BODY

text: of initiation and explanation of the types of crimes they are associated with.
label: BODY

text: The most powerful allure of a gang is the sense of power and respect that is perceived to
label: BODY

text: come with membership; the power of numbers, control of a neighborhood, and fear of
label: BODY

text: their potential for committing random acts of violence, that is mistaken for respect.
label: BODY

text: These misplaced beliefs, in conjunction with a sense of being family or brothers or sisters
label: BODY

text: against other gangs and those who they perceive as being different, creates a sense of
label: BODY

text: unity.  In reality, the love, power, respect, and unity of gang membership is a path to
label: BODY

text: arrest, imprisonment, injury, hospitalization, and death.   A community involvement
label: BODY

text: component of GAP lists the various resources available to discourage gang recruitment
label: BODY

text: efforts.  This includes involvement in alternative structural school activities, increased
label: BODY

text: parental involvement in the education process, and access to professional counseling in
label: BODY

text: schools via accredited private social outreach services. These prevention efforts, to be
label: BODY

text: effective, must be in place to assist students as early as third grade.
label: BODY

text: One OWG sub-committee has developed a bilingual “Guide to School and Community
label: BODY

text: Activities for School Age Children.”  The guide provides parents with a broad variety of
label: BODY

text: supervised and structured activities as an alternate to idle time.  The activities are listed
label: BODY

text: according to a child’s age and grade. (Please see attachment #3 for the current guide).
label: BODY

text: A member of the OWG who was partnered with an officer from the Freeport Police
label: BODY

text: Department Community Response Unit (cru) gave each GAP presentation, and by
label: BODY

text: February 2004, every school PTA in the Freeport School District had a GAP
label: BODY

text: presentation..  Additional presentations are currently offered to any religious
label: BODY

text: congregation or civic association willing to host the program.  Unfortunately, most of the
label: BODY

text: presentations that have taken place were poorly attended.
label: BODY

text: The expansion of Police Department school-based mentoring programs, interagency
label: BODY

text: collaboration and interactive resident/police communications respective to street crime or
label: BODY

text: related activity, supplement the many initiatives described above.  In conjunction with
label: BODY

text: these efforts, the Police Department provides an assessment of the gang issues facing
label: BODY

text: village residents along with insight into existing police-sponsored programs and
label: BODY

text: enforcement operations.   Group dynamics of the OWG participants have afforded the
label: BODY

text: members an opportunity to enhance existing programs.  As discussed prior, the Freeport
label: BODY

text: Police Department "Home Visit Program" (HVP) has been changed to provide an
label: BODY

text: additional resource.  Now when CRU officers visit the homes of known gang members to
label: BODY

text: offer assistance to the gang member's parent(s), an additional service is provided.
label: BODY

text: Freeport Pride, a private youth outreach program, is working with CRU officers to
label: BODY

text: include their social workers in the HVP to offer their assistance and alternate program
label: BODY

text: awareness to the gang members family.
label: BODY

text: Another sub-committee is tasked with researching new programs for students as a
label: BODY

text: deterrent to gang recruitment.  The committee members also arrange for former gang
label: BODY

text: members or other motivational speakers to address student groups.  One sub-committee
label: BODY

text: has the responsibility for researching new law proposals that are designed to deter gang
label: BODY

text: related crime.  Other members are assigned to pursue the development of new initiatives
label: BODY

text: and partnerships with like organizations outside Freeport.  These include the; Hispanic
label: BODY

text: Counseling Center, Family and Children Associations, Nassau County Youth Board,
label: BODY

text: Nassau County Department of Social Services, and the Salvation Army.
label: BODY

text: One of the new initiatives that have been implemented is a student survey. The survey
label: BODY

text: was conducted in anticipation that the results would assist the committee with identifying
label: BODY

text: areas of need that the committee would focus on to better assist students with meeting
label: BODY

text: today's challenges.  The framework of the Search Institute survey evaluates a student’s
label: BODY

text: sense of possessing skills or “Developmental Assets” in the following five categories.
label: BODY

text: 1) On going relationships with caring adults.
label: BODY

text: 2) Safe places and structured activities during non-school hours.
label: BODY

text: 3) A healthy start for a healthy future.
label: BODY

text: 4) Marketable skills through effective education.
label: BODY

text: 5) Opportunities to serve.
label: BODY

text: Currently the OWG is evaluating the results of a Developmental Asset Survey that was
label: BODY

text: given to even grade students from 4th to 12th grades.  The Search Institute vision is to
label: BODY

text: "Have a world where all young people are valued and thrive".  (Please see attachment #4
label: BODY

text: for a descriptive booklet on the survey)
label: BODY

text: While Freeport School students offered responses that are comparable to national average
label: BODY

text: results, the specific asset deficiencies were disheartening.  This is especially true with
label: BODY

text: regard to the following;
label: BODY

text: 1)      Positive family communications-only 16% locally and 28% nationally have this
label: BODY

text: asset
label: BODY

text: 2)      Have high expectations for themselves-56% locally and 48% nationally have this
label: BODY

text: asset
label: BODY

text: 3)      A sense of bonding to the school-38% locally and 52% nationally have this asset
label: BODY

text: 4)      The ability to initiate peaceful conflict resolution-21% locally and 40% nationally
label: BODY

text: 5)      A sense of feeling safe-42% locally and 51% nationally
label: BODY

text: 6)      Have and understand family boundaries-36% locally and 46% nationally
label: BODY

text: 7)      Experience positive peer influence-54% locally and 63% nationally
label: BODY

text: 8) Use time at home constructively-43% locally and 51% nationally
label: BODY

text: 9)      Feel capable of exercising restraint-30% locally and 45% nationally
label: BODY

text: The above survey results, while not specific enticements to gang involvement, help
label: BODY

text: explain the allure of a gang as a surrogate family.  The unity, love and respect that is
label: BODY

text: perceived to be, or is missing in the family, creates a void that gang membership purports
label: BODY

text: to fill.
label: BODY

text: Family values once taken for granted as the foundation for child development have been
label: BODY

text: seriously eroded.   Inappropriate societal influences including entertainment media, video
label: BODY

text: games, and magazines, such as "Don Diva", glorify violence and misogynistic views.
label: BODY

text: These sources, combined with a news media, that sensationalizes horrific acts of
label: BODY

text: violence, become difficult influences for parents and schools to overcome.  In addition, a
label: BODY

text: confused sense as to what constitutes traditional cultural values contributes to minimizing
label: BODY

text: the reservations a person may have with regard to joining a gang.
label: BODY

text: Multi-culturalism without support for the established cultural values & beliefs contributes
label: BODY

text: to national confusion on how to address many of the problems facing society.  A "melting
label: BODY

text: pot" without a common language will become a "Tower of Babble".  The ability to
label: BODY

text: engage in effective communication is an essential element of any successful gang
label: BODY

text: eradication effort.  Confused or misunderstood communications frequently result in
label: BODY

text: unattended and sometimes deadly consequences.  I have witnessed native-born gang
label: BODY

text: members openly discuss their distrust of non-English speaking members of opposing
label: BODY

text: gangs during school gang prevention workshops.
label: BODY

text: The allure of gang membership in some cases originates from a family member.  In many
label: BODY

text: cases either the father or sibling is the pathway to gang membership.  The family legacy
label: BODY

text: road to gang membership is more common within Hispanic gangs, where two or more
label: BODY

text: generations who belong to the same gang may live together.   Even families without a
label: BODY

text: gang member within it are experiencing difficulty with raising their children due to the
label: BODY

text: outside influences.
label: BODY

text: In a recent disturbing trend, the Freeport Police Department has experienced an increase
label: BODY

text: in domestic incident calls that involve parents who state that they are overwhelmed and
label: BODY

text: feels incapable of dealing with the behavioral issues of their child.  Most of these parents
label: BODY

text: are looking for help and guidance.  Others have stated that they don't care about their
label: BODY

text: child and want the Police to take them and place them in jail or any place, just away from
label: BODY

text: them.  These children have been abandoned in place and will be at risk absent meaningful
label: BODY

text: intervention by reinvigorated and accomplished government services.
label: BODY

text: The effectiveness of the programs described herein is difficult to weigh.  In spite of the
label: BODY

text: efforts expended, gangs proliferate in surrounding communities, while their membership
label: BODY

text: numbers remain relatively constant within Freeport.  The gang recruiting that has been
label: BODY

text: thwarted is due to the collective labors of the Freeport Police Department and its many
label: BODY

text: partners.  The total magnitude of the gang activity that has been prevented is an
label: BODY

text: intangible.  The obvious and consensus view is that more needs to be done on the federal,
label: BODY

text: state and local levels.
label: BODY

text: The most important next step is changing the culture to restore values that incorporate
label: BODY

text: and encourage a sense of unity, respect, and devotion to guarantee the rights of others to
label: BODY

text: be free from threats, intimidation or harm.  Free speech issues must be weighed in the
label: BODY

text: context of offense it was intended to cause.  Restrictions on profanity do not restrict a
label: BODY

text: person’s ability to communicate.  Conversely, our ability to communicate would be
label: BODY

text: enhanced by the expansion of vocabulary for the purpose of engaging in persuasive
label: BODY

text: communication without vulgarity.
label: BODY

text: The family must plant courtesy and the skills of positive social interaction during infancy.
label: BODY

text: Overwhelmingly, television has become the primary babysitter of youth.  The social
label: BODY

text: skills developed through this medium bare little resemblance to “Sesame Street” and are
label: BODY

text: more representative of the “Jerry Springer Show.”  Parenting skill programs and related
label: BODY

text: educational programs must find a way into our early child development efforts.  The
label: BODY

text: subsequent benefit to focusing on early development skills and communication programs
label: BODY

text: will achieve benefits in reducing domestic violence, providing academic, and skills
label: BODY

text: learning, all of which are measurable outcomes. They also support a cohesive family unit
label: BODY

text: as the primary deterrent to gang involvement.  Furthermore we must work to ensure that
label: BODY

text: all people are embraced and afforded opportunity as true equals.  This is a daunting task
label: BODY

text: that must be implemented as soon as possible.   Anything less than the timely
label: BODY

text: implementation of these principles will guarantee that our gang prevention efforts will be
label: BODY

text: as successful as the current "war on drugs".
label: BODY
